leafs.name: Galaxies
leafs.blurb: Galaxies are huge collections of stars, dark matter and gas held together by gravity

leafs.name: Galaxy Types
leafs.blurb: There are three main types of galaxies: elliptical, spiral and dwarf

leafs.name: Growth
leafs.blurb: Galaxies grow larger through accretion of gas and mergers with other galaxies

leafs.name: Spiral galaxies
leafs.blurb: Spirals are massive, disk shaped galaxies. They are actively forming new stars. Our galaxy, the Milky Way, is a spiral.

leafs.name: Mergers
leafs.blurb: Galaxies collide often compared to the lifetime of the universe. When they do they tear each other apart in a violent merger.

leafs.name: Elliptical galaxies
leafs.blurb: Ellipticals are the most massive form of galaxy. They are huge spheres of stars in random orbits with no gas or star formation.

leafs.name: Black Holes
leafs.blurb: Black holes are extremely massive objects, whose gravity is so strong that they collapse down to a tiny size.

leafs.name: Black Hole Mergers
leafs.blurb: When two black holes merge they distort the space-time around them

leafs.name: Dwarf galaxies
leafs.blurb: Dwarves are the least massive galaxies.

leafs.name: Gas accretion
leafs.blurb: Galaxies pull gas towards them from their surroundings, feeding new star formation.
